metadata.case_name: Purushottam Umedbhai & Co. v. Manilal Sons

facts.text: Manilal Sons, a firm carrying on business at No. 11A, Malacca Street, Singapore, with five partners: 1. Manubhai Maganbhai Amin, 2. Pravinbhai Dahyabhai Patel, 3. Gangabhai Iswarbhai Patel, 4. Bachubhai Manibhai Amin, 5. Dahyabhai Trikambhai.
Defendant: Purushottam Umedbhai & Co., a firm registered under Indian Partnership Act, 1932, carrying on business at No. 55 Canning Street, Calcutta.
In July 1949, contract between plaintiff and defendant for sale of 950 bales of Heavy Cees gunny bags c.i.f. Singapore to be shipped from Calcutta in August 1949, subject to certain conditions.
In July-August 1949, agreement for defendant to sell 600 bales of Heavy Cees gunny bags c.i.f. Hong Kong to be shipped from Calcutta in August 1949, subject to certain conditions.
Defendant failed to perform contracts, resulting in loss to plaintiff; breach alleged in October and November 1949.
Plaintiff claimed Rs. 2,73,864 as compensation and Rs. 7,850 towards expenses, total Rs. 2,81,714.
Suit No. 1452 of 1951 instituted on April 2, 1951 in Calcutta High Court Original Original Civil Jurisdiction by Manilal Sons.
Defendant's written statement filed on or about May 21, 1951.
On January 29, 1957, solicitors of plaintiff received letter from defendant's attorney objecting that suit framed in name of Singapore firm is null and void and not maintainable.
Suit appeared on peremptory list for first time on January 3, 1957.
Petition for amendment filed January 31, 1957: strike off firm name Manilal Sons and substitute names of five partners as plaintiffs, with consequential amendments; claimed bona fide misdescription.

P.B. Mukherjea J. rejected amendment petition on February 8, 1957: plaint a nullity, not misnomer; proper course to withdraw and file fresh suit under O. XXIII r.1 CPC before limitation; dissatisfied with delay explanation.

Division Bench of Calcutta High Court on December 18, 1958 set aside single judge order, allowed amendment substituting partners' names, permitted signing by partners or attorneys; on condition pay appellants' costs upto judgment date; set aside dismissal of suit.
Manubhai Maganbhai Amin, manager of Manilal Sons, executed Power of Attorney in favour of four persons including Dunderdale, authorizing suit against Purushottam Umedbhai & Co., file plaint etc.
Dunderdale signed and verified the plaint on behalf of Manilal Sons.

legal_issues.text: Whether plaint filed in name of foreign firm (Manilal Sons, Singapore) is a nullity or a misdescription amendable under CPC.
Whether substituting partners' names amounts to adding new parties attracting limitation under s.22(1) Limitation Act.
Whether Power of Attorney by one partner (manager) authorizes filing suit on behalf of firm.
Applicability of O.XXX CPC to foreign firms and effect on suit validity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Plaint as filed was a nullity; suit incompetent; substituting partners adds new parties; if limitation elapsed, suit time-barred.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O.I r.10 CPC; O.VI r.17 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if not nullity, O.I r.10 and O.VI r.17 inapplicable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: O.I r.10 CPC; O.VI r.17 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit by one partner bad ab initio under s.45 Contract Act; amendment converts to new suit barred by limitation.
Adding/substituting new plaintiffs; suit deemed instituted when added, barred by s.22(1) Limitation Act.
No suit in eyes of law; plaint not properly signed/verified.
Power of Attorney by one partner insufficient for firm or all partners.
Reliance on Vyankatesh Oil Mill Co. v. N. Velamahomed: suit by non-existent entity not maintainable; amendment is substitution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Vyankatesh Oil Mill Co. v. N. Velamahomed AIR 1928 Bom 191

respondent_arguments.text: Misdescription of individual partners; amendable; not nullity or non-existent person.
Power of Attorney sufficient; executed by manager.

court_reasoning.text: Firm name is compendious description of partners collectively (s.4 Partnership Act); suit in firm name is suit by partners, misdescription if foreign firm.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not nullity; amendable under s.153 CPC as correcting description.

court_reasoning.text: O.XXX enabling for Indian firms; foreign firms sue individually but misdescription if filed as firm; not adding parties.
court_reasoning.key_observation: O.XXX r.1, r.2 indicate suit in firm name is by partners.

court_reasoning.text: Not adding/substituting parties under O.I r.10; no new plaintiff; limitation not attracted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Partners collectively described as firm from inception.

court_reasoning.text: Manager partner (agent under s.18 Partnership Act) can execute PoA; no prohibition in s.19(2); authorizes suit.
Distinguished Blackwell J. view; followed High Courts like Calcutta, Madras; firm name alias for partners.

holdings.text: Plaint in name of foreign firm is misdescription of partners, not nullity; amendable.
Substitution of partners' names not addition of new parties; no limitation bar.
Power of Attorney by manager partner valid for instituting suit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vyankatesh Oil Mill Co. v. N. Velamahomed
precedents_cited.relevance: Held suit by foreign firm non-existent entity not maintainable; court disagreed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amulakchand Mewaram v. Babulal Kanalal Taliwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Doubted Blackwell view; suit in foreign firm name misdescription.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hajee Sattar Hajee Peer Mahomad v. Khusiram Benarsilal
precedents_cited.relevance: Rejected Blackwell; firm name mere expression, not legal entity.
Firm no legal existence; partners principals/agents.
Dissent from Blackwell; misdescription correctable, no new party.
Pre-O.XXX; adding partner misdescription, not non-joinder.

precedents_cited.case_name: Neogi Ghose and Co. v. Nehal Singh
L. N. Chettiar Firm v. M.P.R.M. Firm

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Amendment for misdescription; O.XXX enabling for Indian firms only; not adding parties.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act, 1932
statutes_cited.relevance: Firm name compendious for partners; partner as agent can execute PoA.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Argued by appellants re suit by one partner; rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: No application as no new parties added.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals by special leave, upheld Division Bench order allowing amendment of plaint by substituting names of partners of Manilal Sons in place of firm name, set aside single judge dismissal of suit; amendment on terms of costs already imposed.
outcome.costs: Costs as per Division Bench order (appellants' costs upto High Court judgment paid by respondents).

key_quotes.text: "Partnership is the relation between persons who have agreed to share the profits of a business carried on by all or any of them acting for all."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines firm as collective partners per s.4 Partnership Act.

key_quotes.text: A firm may not be a legal entity in the sense of a corporation but it is still an existing concern where business is done by a number of persons in partnership.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains suit in firm name is by partners.

key_quotes.text: If however imperfectly and incorrectly a party is designated in a plaint the correction of the error is not the addition or substitution of a party but merely clarifies what was previously shrouded in obscurity.
key_quotes.speaker: court
